bibl.title: Letter from [James E. Peabody] to George Kellogg, December 18, 1929

div1.p: [Peabody] reports on the status of the Congressional campaign to honor the yellow fever heroes, and enlists Kellogg's help in the effort.

div1.head: Letter from [James E. Peabody] to George Kellogg, December 18, 1929
div1.p:
I tried my best to see you during my two days
in Washington, but could not make it. I enclose a copy of my
story of the Conquest of Yellow Fever, together with some of
our campaign literature.

You will see by the carbon copy of my letter
to Col. Wainwright that considerable progress has been made
toward honoring those Yellow Fever Heroes of 1900. We are eager
to have Col. Wainwright join Senator Copeland in completing that
fine piece of work. Would you be willing to drop him a note
thanking him for his devoted work and urging him to stick at the
task till the job is done?

In view of the significance of what we are try-
ing to accomplish, would it be possible to get a strong resolution
of thanks and of approval of the higher pensions for the three
widows adopted by the A.A.A.S. at Iowa? I know it is late, but
I hope it can be done for it will help our campaign enormously.
See enclosed resolutions adopted by the American Public Health
Association. I am sure Surgeon-General Cumming, the president-
elect of this Association, will do all he can for us.

Please tell Frank Thorne I wanted to see him,
also, for I wished to suggest a possible plan for making the
“Science News Letter” of even more value in the high schools.
Will you please give my warm regards to Dr. Ritter, if you see him?
